entry.title: How to unlock Hero Talents in WoW: The War Within
entry.summary:
With Hero Talents being one of WoW: The War Within's main features, it's natural to want to unlock them as soon as possible. If you're jumping into new expansion now, here's everything you need to know about the process.
How to get Hero Talents in WoW: The War Within
When you enter the game with the expansion enabled, if open your Talent Tree, you'll see a third new tree in the middle of the screen. These are your Hero Talents, but they are locked until you meet two key conditions, neither of which are difficult to achieve.
To unlock them, make sure you have The War Within purchased and have begun the new campaign questline. The campaign takes you to the ancient lands of Khaz Algar, and you're required to go there to unlock your Hero Talent tree.
Screenshot by Destructoid
After that, all you need to do is reach level 71, and the new talents will automatically unlock. Simply questing in The War Within should provide more than enough experience to get you there. As you level up from 70 to 80, you’ll earn one Hero Talent point per level, which can only be used on the Hero Talent tree of your choice.
Unlike previous new systems in WoW, there’s no additional questline, trigger, or condition needed to unlock these talents, which is a bit surprising. Still, by following these two straightforward steps, you’ll be able to fully enjoy the new Hero Talents. Like normal talents, Hero Talents can be respecced free of charge, so feel free to play around with and experiment with your class's new powers.

entry.title: Get an exclusive Parrlok pet in World of Warcraft by streaming on Discord
entry.summary:
Pet collectors of World of Warcraft have a relatively unique way to earn a new pet starting today. All they have to do is stream their World of Warcraft adventures to their friends in Discord.
After 15 minutes of streaming WoW to their pals, players will be eligible to claim this pet. This promotion is running until September 8.
For those who haven't seen these before, Discord has a quest system that lets you claim rewards for certain games. It's a fancy promotional tool, but one that can let players nab unique rewards. In Discord, you can view Quests under the Discover tab; find the quest you want, and select Accept.
Once you've accepted the quest, stream World of Warcraft to at least one other person for 15 minutes. Once you're done, you can claim your reward from the quest page. In this case, it's a unique pet. Parrlok is a chunky little cyclopean ogre with a distinct sort of charm. It's a one-of-a-kind pet, as the only other like it is a recolored pet named Garrlok. That one has only been offered in the Trading Post, so there's currently no way to get it unless he cycles back in.
Image by Destructoid
Parrlok isn't just for looks, though. He's a potential new member of your Battle Pet team as well. He's a humanoid with decent health stats, and comes with "Cute as a Button." It's a rare skill for Humanoid battle pets to have, increasing their dodge chance to 33% for 2 rounds. Combined with "Stoneskin," he's quite the little tank.

entry.title: When does Core Keeper 1.0 come out?
entry.summary:
After almost two years, the sandbox adventure game Core Keeper will finally come out of Early Access. With its full launch, there are plenty of new features to behold, unraveling the secrets of the ancient Core. We're here to dig into Core Keeper 1.0's release date and unveil upcoming content.
Core Keeper 1.0 release date and features
Core Keeper 1.0 will be released on Aug. 27, 2024. This date also marks the game's official console debut, including PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and Xbox One. According to the Nintendo page, the title will also launch on the Switch on Sept. 17, 2024.
The Core Keeper 1.0 content reveal trailer confirms a new and customizable world generation feature, allowing you to explore your favorite biomes. Plus, you can try out the two new combat styles: Warlock and Mage. Explore a unique magic system that requires the power of mana and unlock additional skills for character builds. You'll also uncover a new talent tree for Magic and Summoning, which helps with attack damage and mana regeneration.
The developer, Pugstorm, has given us the deets on Core Keeper's co-op and cross-platform availability. While online multiplayer continues to be worked upon, there are no plans for local co-op or cross-platform support. On the other hand, multiplayer will be revamped for PC crossplay as the team looks into the new PlayFab Party.
If you've played Core Keeper in Early Access, Pugstorm recommends starting a new world to make the 1.0 experience run smoothly. Any old worlds will be renamed as "Classic," indicating that it is an unsupported version for the full release. You can still access these builds afterward, but they won't include 1.0 content.
Image via Pugstorm
Once Core Keeper 1.0 arrives, more updates will roll out to expand the magical universe. That means you can anticipate new content and quality-of-life improvements in the near future.

entry.title: Richtofen and Wunderwaffe take the stage in CoD: Black Ops 6 Liberty Falls cinematic
entry.summary:
Call of Duty: Black Ops 6's Liberty Falls cinematic unveils an exclusive first look at Edward Richtofen's return, bringing the Wunderwaffe along for the ride.
The cinematic begins with a nightmarish series of events as Richtofen horrifically dreams about death and destruction. If you've been a longtime fan of the Black Ops series, you'll likely notice the familiar voice talents of Nolan North. Although his role hasn't been confirmed yet, fans are already buzzing in the comments about his return. His comeback isn't too surprising, given that North has been teasing Richtofen's comeback.

As a longtime Black Ops fan, seeing Edward Richtofen through the lens of modern graphics is certainly a sight to behold. And having Nolan North voice him again makes it even more epic, bringing me back to the days when I first saw the character in Origins.
While Richtofen looks to be the "hero" of the Liberty Falls cinematic, the Terminus Team, the playable crew of Black Ops 6, think otherwise. The Terminus trailer indicates that Edward will be the main target of the BO6 Zombies saga as a plot to seek revenge. He has done plenty of wrongdoings in previous entries, so now his past is finally catching up to him.
There's still a lot of mystery surrounding the Black Ops 6 Zombies story, but fortunately, the upcoming CoD Next event offers more insight into this. So, if you want some more Richtofen, tune into the event on Aug. 28 to get ready for BO6's Beta release.

entry.title: How to find Trading Post in No Man’s Sky
entry.summary:
Trading Posts or Trade Outposts in No Man’s Sky are present on planets in all star systems with lifeforms. They serve a variety of purposes and are a good pitstop to buy and sell items using a Galactic Trade Terminal, like the one you find in Space Stations.
However, trading posts are not useful if you need resources in bulk, as you won’t find as much quantity here as you would at a space station. However, rarer resources will be found at a Galatic Trade Terminal here, as compared to the ones on a Space Station, and for a lower price to boot.
With seven Landing Pads available, Trading Posts may serve as a decent spot to go starship-hunting and finally stumble upon an elusive S-class starship which you may have been tirelessly looking for in the game.
Image via Hello Games
You may find Trading Posts by simply exploring a planet and discovering it from a distance, but that’s down to pure luck since planets in No Man’s Sky are massive. A much simpler and more effective way is to install an Economy Scanner in your starship, which lets you access the quick menu when in the starship to find a nearby trading post on the planet.
There are other ways to find a Trading Post, but the Economy Scanner is the only guaranteed way to locate them. If you cannot build an Economy Scanner, you can use a Planetary Chart (inhabited outpost) or a Signal Booster, but both will reveal information on any kind of structure, making them a trial-and-error method.
One more sneaky suggestion: Sometimes, you may find starships in a planet’s atmosphere that are not heading out towards space. If you follow these starships, they may also lead you to a trading post.

entry.title: Super Scaler inspired racing game Victory Heat Rally is out in October
entry.summary:
Skydevilpalm has announced that the long-anticipated racing game Victory Heat Rally, finally has a release date. It will be out on PC October 3, 2024. And also mobile via the Crunchyroll Game Vault if you’re into that sort of thing.
Victory Heat Rally is a high-speed arcade racing game based on Sega’s quasi-3D super-scaler games like Power Drift. It’s also, last I checked, absolutely fantastic. I played the demo about a year ago. I came away several steps above impressed; somewhere in the realm of “enthusiastic.” It’s fast, colorful, and packed with personality.
It’s been a long time coming. It had a successful Kickstarter campaign back in 2020, but development was a bit slow. It’s a small team, and the primary developer had a child, leading to them trying to adopt a healthier work/life balance. A release window was announced for Winter 2024, so it's going to be a bit early. But what can you do? Game development can be unpredictable.
I’m happy to see its impending release. There is a complete dearth of arcade-style racing games these days. Some are arriving that cop a feel from Saturn and PS1 games. However, pre-3D racing games are among my favorite takes on the genre. I’ll be really jazzed if someone makes a new cross-country title like Rad Mobile.
Victory Heat Rally releases on PC October 3, 2024.

entry.title: Saber boss explains Space Marine 2's microtransactions: “People don’t want to be sold horse armour anymore"

Still, it does sound like he’s managing to have some fun there, mainly by hitting up Saber Interactive COO and former id Software co-owner Tim Willits for some top tips on how to avenge Edwin’s thieving ways. Tips about kill-stealing aside, James found time to ask Willits about Space Marine 2's microtransactions, and whether there was any nervousness returning to a cult hit series… especially one a lot of people had almost given up on ever seeing again. “Even the “push forward” combat of the original was part of [id’s] inspiration when we created Doom 2016,” answered Willits. “So for me personally, it’s this huge circle. It’s not just the horror setting, but the Grimm’s fairytale threat, the distorted adults-made-monsters through the trauma-tinged lens of a child’s imagination. A long-limbed man riding a bicycle in a threadbare suit chases children down an alley. A gangly, bowler-hatted pursuer scuttles down a long table like a spider. entry.title: After three hours of Bloober's Silent Hill 2, it's unclear who is remaking who
entry.summary:
Silent Hill has a messy, up-is-down relationship with time and history, so let's go about this hands-on with the Silent Hill 2 Remake in a messy, up-is-down way. Developed well over two decades ago, the original Silent Hill 2 is the magnum opus of Polish horror stalwarts Bloober Team. Running on then-innovative "Unreal Engine 5" technology created by Jazz Jackrabbit publishers Epic MegaGames, it's a wonderful abyss of a game that remains perfectly playable today, given a certain amount of tolerance for the quirks of the era. It begins with your character, James Sunderland, descending from the road towards the eponymous Midwestern nowhere-town. Like many games of the period, Silent Hill 2 uses a third-person, over-the-shoulder manual camera, which allows you to glance fearfully up at the monstrous pine trees that fringe the path - each rising from a bulging tide of fog that menaces with the suggestion of approaching figures. There is moisture everywhere, gushing from drain pipes and dribbling down concrete barriers. As you amble into the murk, deathly chords and groaning, unmechanical motifs reverberate from somewhere deep underground.

entry.title: Why didn't Silent Hill 2 Remake studio Bloober start by remaking Silent Hill 1? The devs explain

When Bloober and Konami announced that they were remaking Silent Hill 2 as part of a comprehensive series reboot, it made immediate if slightly deflating sense to me. Silent Hill 2 is the more feted of the Hills - if I were a calculating franchise custodian tasked with 'bringing back' one of the acclaimed original trilogy, that's probably the instalment I and my spreadsheets would fix upon. I mean, it's the game with Pyramid Head in it - the nearest thing Silent Hill has to a mascot, and it's not like there's an issue of cutting out plot material: each game in the Silent Hill series is, on some level, a distinct story with a distinct protagonist. Still, the decision to 'skip' the first game in the series, whose world, narrative themes, music and art direction set the parameters for all the rest, made my brain itch a bit, and when I ran into Bloober's creative director Mateusz Lenart and lead producer Maciej Głomb at a Konami event, I had to ask about it.

entry.title: The Dead Rising remaster no longer gives you points for "Erotica" creepshots because it's not "required" or "appropriate"
entry.summary: Aside from being a game where you run around a shopping mall murdering the living dead, the original Dead Rising from 2006 is a clownish satire of sleazy tabloid photojournalism. It expresses this by way of its scoring system, where you earn "Prestige points" for snapping pictures that fit one of five categories: "Brutal" scenes of characters being slain; moments of "Horror", such as the spectacle of an approaching horde; comical "Outtakes", like characters caught in bizarre poses; moments of "Drama", such as people reacting to discoveries; and "Erotic" photos of women alive or undead, which range from snaps of exposed underwear to close-ups of cleavage. The Erotica tag has, however, been chopped from the Dead Rising Deluxe Remaster, in what Capcom gingerly suggest isn't "a response to a changing cultural climate", but expressive of the view that earning points from such photos is not "an appropriate reward for survival and not a skill required of a journalist trying to stay alive". entry.title: Even with some annoyances, game streaming can feel like a Steam Deck cheat code
entry.summary: The Steam Deck’s competitors, whether they’re the old guard Ayaneo family, the luxe Asus ROG Ally X, or the shapeshifting Lenovo Legion Go, usually share the same attack line: they can play more of your games. The Deck’s compatibility issues aren’t nearly as issue-some as they were at launch, but between its Linux-based SteamOS and its relatively mild processing power, but it is true that beefier Windows handhelds will more likely cater to your entire cross-launcher library. Unless, that is, you get something else to run them for you. Streaming games on the Steam Deck has emerged as a nifty workaround for the portable PC’s lingering compatibility woes, making even officially unsupported games playable. Usually with much better performance, too, as the actual rendering work is done remotely – what you see on the Deck’s screen is basically a video feed of that remote device’s display output, with your control input beamed the other way via a low-latency connection. And because you’re not using SteamOS or the internal hardware to actually run the game, it’s not bound by their limits. Read more
